review.title: Duluth at SemEval--2016 Task 14 : Extending Gloss Overlaps to Enrich Semantic Taxonomies
review.abstract: This paper describes the Duluth systems that participated in Task 14 of SemEval 2016, Semantic Taxonomy Enrichment. There were three related systems in the formal evaluation which are discussed here, along with numerous post--evaluation runs. All of these systems identified synonyms between WordNet and other dictionaries by measuring the gloss overlaps between them. These systems perform better than the random baseline and one post--evaluation variation was within a respectable margin of the median result attained by all participating systems.

sections.heading: 2 Systems
sections.text: All Duluth systems start with the pre-processing of both WordNet and OtherDict gloss, which consists of removing any character that is not alphanumeric, and then converting all remaining characters into lowercase letters. Connections known to WordNet will be identified in the WordNet gloss, but not in the way it turns out in the OtherDict gloss. This has most likely reduced the number of overlaps we have found, since a WordNet connection such as a light year will not coincide with a light year, which is the form used in OtherDict.In the following sections, we will describe the Duluth systems. Since the only distinction between them is how they reconstruct WordNet gloss, we will provide a running example to illustrate each system. We will use the cat # n # 1 noun for this purpose. The original WordNet entry for these glosses (before these are predators) indicates that they are # predators.

sections.heading: 2.1 Duluth2
sections.text: Duluth2 is the most basic of the Duluth systems. Each WordNet sense is represented by its sheen, in which all the stopwords and single-letter words have been removed. The stoplist comes from the Ngram Statistics Package (Banerjee and Pedersen, 2003a) and includes 392 words. To continue our example, the first noun sense of cats is represented by Duluth2, as shown below - it was simply pre-processed and then stopwords removed. • Cat # 1: supple, round-headed and retractable in fissipedal mammals This system provides a baseline for the overlap measure as we compare the original Wordnet and OtherDict gloss after minimal pre-processing.

sections.heading: 2.2 Duluth1
sections.text: Duluth1 is a natural extension of Duluth2, where each WordNet gloss is extended by concatenating with it (in the following order): the gloss of the hypernyms of sense3, the gloss of all hyponyms of sense, the gloss of each derived form of sense, and the gloss of all meronyms of sense. This greatly increases the size of each WordNet gloss, to the point where our original attempts to use these extended gloss simply in accordance took too much time to finish during the available time window for evaluation. sections.heading: 2.3 Duluth4
sections.text: Duluth4 is similar to Duluth1 in that it expands the WordNet glosses, but only with the glosses of its hypernyms and hyponyms (and not with the derivatives or meronyms, such as Duluth1). Stopwords are removed by using the same list as Duluth2.We can see in our running example that this offers a greater sheen, but is not as big as Duluth1 (before trimming it down to the first nine words). • Cat mammal # 1: supple, rounded, columnar mammals with retractable claws that eat terrestrial flesh, four five-headed cats with thick fur, which are usually feral cats.

sections.heading: 2.4 Duluth3
sections.text: There are many minor variations between words in WordNet and OtherDict glosses, and it is difficult to normalize the glosses to eliminate them. Instead, we opted for a system based on character trigrams, since it could allow matches between parts of words, rather than requiring the exact matches that all other Duluth systems insist on. Duluth3 expands each WordNet gloss with the gloss of its hypernyms and hyponyms (such as Duluth4, although stop words are not eliminated in Duluth3), then all spaces are removed from each extended gloss and it is broken into three character grams. Glosses were limited to 250 of these trigrams, mainly so that they can be executed within the available time during evaluation. If you study the running example carefully, you can reconstruct the gloss that is similar to Duluth4, except that it contains stops.

sections.heading: 3 Results and Discussion
sections.text: Despite seemingly significant differences in the way WordNet glosses were extended, Table 1 shows that there were only minor differences in results between Duluth1, Duluth2, and Duluth3, which seems to support the conclusion that glossy overlaps provide a reliable and robust starting point for this problem.

Recall that Duluth4 is an obvious extension of Duluth2, broadening the glosses with its hypernym and hyponyms, resulting in a modest but significant improvement in the systems submitted for formal evaluation, suggesting that focusing on the extended glosses content can pay off in a relatively straightforward way. At the very least, this system is beginning to approach the mean achieved by the systems participating in the task. However, even this result lags considerably behind the baseline First Word (Jurgens and Pilehvar, 2015).

sections.heading: 4 System Implementation Details
sections.text: The Duluth systems are implemented using UMLS:: Similarity, which provides semantic kinship and similarity metrics for the Unified Medical Language System. In addition, it also allows a user-provided dictionary to be automatically included and used in the read measurement. Thus, the Duluth systems created dictionaries from OtherDict and WordNet that were suitable for use by reading measurement in UMLS:: Similarity (via the -dict option).
